Package lib.graphs

Class Graph<T>

java.lang.Object
lib.graphs.Graph<T>
Type Parameters:
T - the type of elements contained in the graph
All Implemented Interfaces:
GraphADT<T>
Direct Known Subclasses:
Network
public class Graph<T>
extends java.lang.Object
implements GraphADT<T>
The Graph class represents a graph data structure that can hold vertices and edges. It supports operations for adding and removing vertices and edges, as well as traversal methods and utility functions for graph analysis. This implementation uses an adjacency matrix to represent edges and has dynamic resizing capabilities for storing vertices.

  • Constructor Summary

    Constructors 
    Constructor Description
    Graph()
    Constructs an empty graph with an initial default capacity for vertices.

  • Constructor Details

    • Graph

      public Graph()
      Constructs an empty graph with an initial default capacity for vertices. Initializes the adjacency matrix and the array to hold vertex values.

  • Method Details

    • addVertex

      public void addVertex​(T vertex)
      Adds a vertex to the graph. If the graph has reached its current capacity, it automatically doubles the capacity to accommodate the new vertex. The vertex is added to the array of vertices, and the adjacency matrix is updated to include the new vertex with no edges initially.
      Specified by:
      addVertex in interface GraphADT<T>
      Parameters:
      vertex - the vertex to be added to the graph
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the vertex is null

    • removeVertex

      public void removeVertex​(T vertex) throws ElementNotFoundException
      Removes a specified vertex from the graph. This method updates the adjacency matrix, shifts the vertices array, and ensures the graph's structure remains consistent. If the specified vertex is not found in the graph, an ElementNotFoundException is thrown.
      Specified by:
      removeVertex in interface GraphADT<T>
      Parameters:
      vertex - the vertex to be removed from the graph
      Throws:
      ElementNotFoundException - if the specified vertex is not found in the graph

    • addEdge

      public void addEdge​(T vertex1, T vertex2)
      Adds an edge between two specified vertices in the graph. This method determines the index of each vertex and uses the corresponding indices to establish the connection in the adjacency matrix. If either of the vertices is null, the method does not add the edge and prints an error message.
      Specified by:
      addEdge in interface GraphADT<T>
      Parameters:
      vertex1 - the first vertex to be connected by the edge
      vertex2 - the second vertex to be connected by the edge

    • addEdge

      public void addEdge​(int index1, int index2)
      Adds an edge between two vertices in the graph using their indices. This method updates the adjacency matrix to indicate the presence of an edge between the specified vertices. If either of the indices is invalid, the edge is not added.
      Parameters:
      index1 - the index of the first vertex
      index2 - the index of the second vertex

    • removeEdge

      public void removeEdge​(T vertex1, T vertex2) throws ElementNotFoundException
      Removes an edge between two specified vertices in the graph. This method identifies the corresponding indices of the vertices in the graph, and updates the adjacency matrix to remove the edge connecting them. If either vertex is not present in the graph, an ElementNotFoundException is thrown.
      Specified by:
      removeEdge in interface GraphADT<T>
      Parameters:
      vertex1 - the first vertex connected by the edge to be removed
      vertex2 - the second vertex connected by the edge to be removed
      Throws:
      ElementNotFoundException - if either vertex1 or vertex2 is not found in the graph

    • removeEdge

      public void removeEdge​(int index1, int index2)
      Removes an edge between two vertices in the graph using their indices. If the indices are valid, the adjacency matrix is updated to remove the connection. If either index is invalid, the method does nothing.
      Parameters:
      index1 - the index of the first vertex
      index2 - the index of the second vertex

    • iteratorBFS

      public java.util.Iterator<T> iteratorBFS​(T startVertex) throws EmptyCollectionException
      Returns an iterator that performs a breadth-first search (BFS) traversal starting from the specified vertex.
      Specified by:
      iteratorBFS in interface GraphADT<T>
      Parameters:
      startVertex - the vertex to begin the BFS traversal from
      Returns:
      an iterator that performs a breadth-first traversal starting at the given vertex
      Throws:
      EmptyCollectionException - if the graph is empty or the traversal cannot be performed

    • iteratorDFS

      public java.util.Iterator<T> iteratorDFS​(T startVertex) throws EmptyCollectionException
      Returns an iterator that performs a depth-first search (DFS) traversal starting from the specified vertex. This method determines the index of the start vertex and delegates the DFS traversal to the overloaded method that operates on indices.
      Specified by:
      iteratorDFS in interface GraphADT<T>
      Parameters:
      startVertex - the vertex from which to begin the DFS traversal
      Returns:
      an iterator that performs a depth-first traversal starting at the given vertex
      Throws:
      EmptyCollectionException - if the graph is empty or the traversal cannot be performed

    • iteratorBFS

      public java.util.Iterator<T> iteratorBFS​(int startIndex) throws EmptyCollectionException
      Returns an iterator that performs a breadth first search traversal starting at the given index.
      Parameters:
      startIndex - the index to begin the search from
      Returns:
      an iterator that performs a breadth first traversal
      Throws:
      EmptyCollectionException

    • iteratorDFS

      public java.util.Iterator<T> iteratorDFS​(int startIndex) throws EmptyCollectionException
      Returns an iterator that performs a depth first search traversal starting at the given index.
      Parameters:
      startIndex - the index to begin the search traversal from
      Returns:
      an iterator that performs a depth first traversal
      Throws:
      EmptyCollectionException

    • iteratorShortestPath

      public java.util.Iterator<T> iteratorShortestPath​(T startVertex, T targetVertex) throws ElementNotFoundException
      Returns an iterator over the shortest path between two vertices in the graph. The method applies a modified Dijkstra's algorithm to compute the shortest path in an unweighted graph and constructs the path if it exists. If either the start or target vertex is not found, an ElementNotFoundException is thrown.
      Specified by:
      iteratorShortestPath in interface GraphADT<T>
      Parameters:
      startVertex - the vertex where the shortest path starts
      targetVertex - the vertex where the shortest path ends
      Returns:
      an iterator over the vertices in the shortest path from startVertex to targetVertex, or an empty iterator if no path exists
      Throws:
      ElementNotFoundException - if either startVertex or targetVertex is not found in the graph

    • isEmpty

      public boolean isEmpty()
      Determines whether the graph is empty.
      Specified by:
      isEmpty in interface GraphADT<T>
      Returns:
      true if the graph contains no vertices, false otherwise

    • isConnected

      public boolean isConnected() throws EmptyCollectionException
      Determines whether the graph is connected. A graph is considered connected if all vertices are reachable from any single vertex, meaning there exists a path between every pair of vertices. If the graph contains no vertices, it is deemed not connected.
      Specified by:
      isConnected in interface GraphADT<T>
      Returns:
      true if the graph is connected, false otherwise
      Throws:
      EmptyCollectionException - if the graph is empty or traversal cannot be performed

    • size

      public int size()
      Returns the number of vertices in the graph.
      Specified by:
      size in interface GraphADT<T>
      Returns:
      the total number of vertices currently present in the graph
